titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VII. Monday— First Session 18th. Congress commences— H Clay, Speaker H.R.U.S— W. N. Edwards & R. D. Spaight here— G. Johnson, going to Alexandria— Transfer of Metropolis Bank Stock to Columbian College— Harvey and Malcomson at the Office, for copies of Records. Tuyll and Stackelberg— Death of F. Greuhm, Prussian Minister. Arrangements for his funeral— Addington—iron duties— At P.U.S. Greuhm’s funeral arrangements— M’Ilvaine, Senator from New-Jersey and his Son— E. Wyer— After dinner I called on Gaillard and Clay— At Carbery’s— He at my house— Also Stackelberg and Petry.

2. VI:30. Visitors at my house— Crowninshield, Durfey, Farrelly, Fuller, Holcombe, Kent, Mitchell, Spence, Reynolds, Saunders, Little and Plumer of New-Hampshire all members H.R.— Notes from and to Barons Tuyll and Stackelberg.— At P.U.S. His directions— Marshal Ringgold— Dined at Petry’s— Talk about Salazar— Evening Call on Clay. J. Randolph’s ideas— Clay’s opinions of the Message and his projects. His Son— Letcher— J. C. Wright. Call on Gaillard— Holmes and Bell there— Course of the two houses— Home at 11. P.M.

3. VI. G. Johnson at my house— About his books— Marshal Ringgold— Funeral Arrangements— Visitors J. C. Wright, Letcher, J. T. Vinton, D. White, Buchanan, Markley, Rich, Crafts, (Robinson) Burton, Mangum Buck and Bradley— Bailey came with S. Larned, Secretary of Legation to go to Chili— Fuller at the Office— Tuyll and Stackelberg. At P.U.S. Calhoun came in. The Message— Abolition of privateering— Crowninshield & Bradley—proposed explanatory paragraph. E. Wyer and H. Johnson here this Eve.

4. VI. Lieutt. Weed here— Rain Storm— Marine Corps countermanded Greuhm’s funeral from Dr Laurie’s Church— Service performed— Procession to Navy-yard burying ground— Southard went with me— Spoke of Dickerson— Back about 2. Keating— J. Mason jr. at the Office— At P.U.S. Gales there— Company to dine with us— Dwight, Garnett, Gomez, Larned, J. Mason jr. Newton, Palacio, Poinsett Salazar, Swartwout, D. Trimble and Vallenilla— Petry here in the Evening— Cards.

5. VI:15.G. Hay here—recommending Duncan, Rich, Slade, G. Tucker, of Va.Ruggles, Patterson of Ohio, Sloan, Whittlesey, Carter and Cushman— At the Office Mallary, Cassedy, Sterling—and Nelson about Keating— Cabinet Meeting. Calhoun & Southard— Instructions to R. Rush— About E. Everett
and Greece— J. Connell at the Office— Claims on France, Denmark and Sweden— Call of S. Wood at my house— Thermometer Register. G. Johnson’s Books.

6: VII. Numerous visitors, members of Congress and others: among whom Generals Jackson and Eaton of Tennessee, and General S. Smith of Maryland, and Coll. R. M. Johnson of Kentucky; with his brother J. T. Johnson of H. R.—also Messrs.Allison, John S. Barbour, Farrelly, Bradley, D. P. Cook, Fuller, L. Williams, Gatlin, Burleigh, and Hogeboom— Burton, Foote of Connecticut, LitchfieldWilson of New-York, Frost and Tyson. The rest left cards— G. Hay and Wyer; at my house, and Mr. Addington and Mr Bailey at the Office— G. Hay gave me the Letters of Recommendation for Duncan, and Alr. Smyth’s circular. Dined at Commodore Morris’s— Evening Petry here— Cards.

7. VI:30. Heard Baker. A.M. Psalm 91.9. Funeral discourse. Call on R. King. Genl. van Rensselaer— At Forsyth’s— At O’Neale’s, and saw General Jackson, General Eaton, and Genl. Call, Delegate from Florida. Missed the afternoon service— Evening heard Mr. Little. Luke 20.37.38. A future state of retribution— Cushman there— Call afterwards at Fletcher’s— D. P. Cook, James Strong and eight or ten other members of Congress there— Home late— Wrote little.

8. VII— Third Instruction to R. Rush— Bradley of Vermont here. Of C. P. Van Ness and his claims as Commissioner— Of S. Smith, his letter and calculation— Of Barclay and Chipman &c— Visits from members of Congress—Houstoun, Blair, Eddy, Cobb, Tomlinson, WhitmanHamilton of S.C. and Poinsett. Cobb, to speak of a Letter concerning Yazoo claims that he wrote me last week— Poinsett spoke of Webster’s Resolution for a Commissioner to Greece—Guatimala and Cuba— At P.U.S. He kept the draft to R. Rush. Dinner to the Diplomatic Corps on Friday next— At my Office. Sullivan. The Massachusetts claim— Tuyll—the diplomatic dinner— Again at P.U.S. Invites Salazar— H. Johnson. Letter to Prevost— Wyer. Eve writing.

9. VI:15. Visitors, members of Congress, Rogers, M’Kean, R. M. Johnson, J. T. Johnson, Wickliffe, Henry— Then Mr Southard, with copy of Instructions to Captain Hull— Afterwards Mr Grafton Duval, and Mr S. Larned— At the Office. Tomlinson for a Passport.
Armstrong, for Instructions to go to Hayti— Randall, to go to the Havanna, Hickey for G. Boyd’s Letters of instructions in 1815 which has been found— J. Connell upon French Claims— At the President’s— Hull to be instructed to wait for the Peacock. Bailey— Dined at the President’s— Chiefly members of Congress— Mrs Adams’s first Tuesday Evening party for the Season—about 120. Snow.

div.p: 10. VI:15.Mr Henry of Kentuckey here, about changing one of the Printers of the Laws in that State—too late for this Session— Mr M’Lean Postmaster General, here, with his brother, a member from Ohio— Roads and Canals— Mr Cushman of Maine— About the Northeastern boundary— Letter from Governor Parris— Anti-caucussing. Letter to R. Rush— At the Office. James Brown— Appointed Minister to France; and resigned yesterday his seat in Senate— Alexr. M’Rae— Going to England and France— Also to New-York— W. Duane and De Witt Clinton— Two new Richmond Papers— J. Forsyth, Chairman Committee Foreign Relations H.R— Papers to be sent him—omission from the Message—

11. VI:30—Cushman here, with the copy of the Instruction to R. Rush on the Boundary— Wishes it to be communicated to Governor Parris— D. P. Cook. About Dr Steele— Also of N. Edwards and a Mission to Mexico. G. Johnson— Mill Prospects dull. W. Plumer— About the New-Hampshire Patriot Newspaper— Jessee B. Thomas Senator from Illinois— Mr Clay’s son; Mr Conway, delegate from Arkansas, and another Mr George Hay, with a Letter from Pleasants— His projected newspaper. Francis Johnson and a Mrof Kentuckey. Note from P.U.S. A Cabinet Meeting— Calhoun and Southard present— Proposals from N. Biddle President Bank U.S. Specie to be brought from Mexico— Question upon prohibiting the naval Officers from receiving Specie, in all or in any case— Calhoun’s opinions— Southard’s for prohibition— Mine for a regulation by Law—decision suspended— Remarks of P.U.S. . . . Edwards of Illinois—and Forsyth— At the Office— Armstrong, W. Lee— M’Rae— Brown— Company to dine. Bell, Breck, Brown, Buchanan, Crowninshield, Durfee, Eaton, Fuller, Gaillard, Genl. Jackson, Lloyd, Markley, Mitchell, TaylorVinton and Wright. Dr Kent sent an excuse— Conversation after dinner with Taylor— N. Biddle. Evening here— Verses for Miss Mease—

div.p: 12. VI:30.Mr D. Brent called this morning— Baron Tuyll’s proposals concerning Madame Greuhm. Monies of her husband in Bank averse to taking out. Letters of Administration— G. Hay here. Letter from J. H. Pleasants; uncertain whether to answer him or not— Coll. R. M. Johnson— His remarks upon Caucussing— Van Buren and James Barbour— Their labours to get up a Caucus— Van Buren’s solicitations to him— His resistance— Resolutions of the Tennessee Legislature against a Caucus—to be communicated to H.R.— Motion to refer them to a Committee; for a Report— M’Rae at the Office. His project to see De Witt Clinton—utterly disapproved by me. At the President’s— Letter to Minister of State of Peru—draft. Calhoun, and Southard there— Shipments of specie in public vessels lawful. Dined at P.U.S— N. Biddle went with me— Diplomatic dinner Baron Tuyll and Salazar— Eve at home— Petry— Cards.

13. VI:30.James Barbour, Chairman of the Committee of foreign Relations of the Senate— Holy Alliance and South-America. J. S. Barbour with Moore of Kentuckey— Dr Abbot— Edwards Senator from Connecticut, with Ogden Edwards and Gardner. Blair, Standifer and Isaacs of Tennessee and Dr. CondictJames Johnson and George Johnson were also here— R. M. Johnson, Francis Johnson, Thomson and Buckner at the Office— Also M’Rae, Connell and Wyer— More of the Caucus— Isaacs is to present the Tennessee Resolutions, and to move the reference— R. M. Johnson’s remarks about the Vice-Presidency, and judge Thomson’s expectation flattered by Van Buren, of a New-York nomination to the Presidency— At the Presidents— Mrs Greuhm and Petry for passages with Mr And Mrs Brown— Letter to J. B. Prevost— Despatches from Sheldon and Appleton— Evening Addington. Wallenstein and Biddle here— Drowsy.

14. VII. Heard Dr Staughton at the Capitol— Matthew 13.3. . .. Visits to Edwards of North Carolina at Dowson’s. To Beecher, Henry and Dr. Abbot at Burch’s—to J. W. Taylor, with LivermoreStewart and E. A. Brown. Conversation with Taylor— Then several other visits by Cards— Visit from Count de Menou. Madame de la Rue—Beaumarchais—daughter.— To speak to Webster— Heard Baker P.M— John 12.27— Visit to Coll.DwightMarkley and Fuller— Talk with Fuller. Eve at Dr Thornton’s.

15. VII. Draft of Instruction to A. M’Rae— At the Office— James Brown. Examination of Gallatin’s correspondence. At P.U.S. Approves the draft— Southard there. District Attorney—New-Jersey—Jeffers. Elmer. Despatch from Sheldon— O’Brien at the Office— His renewed claims. His politics— A. M’Rae— To go to-morrow— Armstrong— Despatched him for Hayti— Martindale— Wished a change of printers of the Laws in State of New York— Appointments for this Session already made. Tennessee Resolutions not offered this day— Stackelberg here this Eve.

div.p: 16. VI. Call at O. Brown’s— R. M. Johnson out. At the Post-Office— Met Calhoun there—and R. M. Johnson— Isaacs’s Resolutions not brought forward. Given up— Recommended Joseph C. Melcher—Post-Office New Bedford. Call at C. B. King’s. Copying Portrait of Columbus. At P.U.S. with draft of Letter to J. B. Prevost— Read the papers— The President approved the draft— At the Office— G. Hay— Proclamation offering reward for arrest of Brown—Fugitive from New-Orleans— Arrested by M’Rae; whose creditors now apply for the reward— Would apply to R. Rush— I decline. Larned to go to Chili and to be despatched to-morrow— Advance. Alr. Burton, with despatches from H. Nelson. Gibraltar 2. Novr— Dr. Thornton— The Caucus. 129 members pledged to attend— Macon to preside. M’Kim Colombian Privateer at Baltimore— M’Kim for seizing her. Objections. Call on P.U.S. order to Secy Navy to convoy her— To remonstrate with Salazar against it— Bailey— The Caucus— Fuller—the same. Blount at my house this Evening.

17. VI:30.E. Wyer here this Morning— His talk with Judge White, and Reynolds of Tennessee. T. Newton, Chairman Comee. Commerce— Discriminating duty Laws— W. Elliot here, for Columbian Institute— Their Garden. F. Johnson of Kentuckey, with Yancey—to see the sight of a S.S— At the Office— At last despatched Alr. M’Rae— Could not despatch Larned— M’Kim came again—the Colombian privateer gone from Baltimore— Insurance could not be obtained for the merchant vessel— Sent for Salazar— He came— Told him of the privateer— His regret—promised to write to his Government— Alr. Burton— His expenses from Wilmington, and to New-York. Despatches from H. Nelson and Appleton— Cadix 6. Novr.— Dined with G. Sullivan— Small company— Free Conversation— Went with Fuller to his lodgings— Saw Dwight— Told him how to send money to the Greeks. G. Tucker came in— Spoke of Weights and Measures— Home at 11. Found Petry there— Cards two hours— Late retirement.

18. VII:30—Rice here— Wants more Metropolis Bank Stock— Noble Senator from Indiana, and Test Member H.R. from the same State here— Durfee, to recommend Robins as Secretary of Legation— His Recommendations of Larned explained— Wyer here— At the Office— Note from P.U.S. Communications to Comee. foreign Relations S.U.S. Call Delegate from Florida—Documents and Accounts. Crowninshield. Claims of Devereux and others— Spanish seizure. Long Conversation upon politics—Russell and 1816. Crawford’s intention to resign &c. Menou— Question on the Construction of the Convention of June 1822. and six Months notice of its termination— Remarks upon the policy of France— Menou’s embarrassment and reserve. Company to dine Beecher, Bradley, Buckner, Calhoun, Cambreleng, Clay, and his Son. FarrellyHayne, J. Holmes, H. Johnson, Litchfield, Little, Reynolds, S. Smith and Webster— P. Sharpe and Spence invited did not come. Evening Ball at Genl. Brown’s— Crowd— Mercer’s explanations.

19. VII:30. Heavy morning rain, then clearing up moderate. R. King here— Long conversation with him— His motive for declining to act, on the Senate’s Committee of Foreign Relations— His communications with Van Buren; who says he has “missed a figure,” himself. His Treaties and Intreaties with S. Thompson— His projected supper, and political windings— King’s intention to resign. Thinks Sanford will succeed him. At the Office— Baker the Clergyman. Questions concerning a Legacy of eighty years standing in South-Carolina. Church contributions. At P.U.S. met Calhoun there. Also H. Johnson, and E. Livingston President’s remarks about Forsyth, and his projects. Mission to Mexico. Dined at Captain Chauncey’s. Naval and Diplomatic Company. Offer to Petry to go in the Cyane— Talk about abolition of private War on the Sea— Home between 9 and 10. J. W. Taylor here. Tennessee Resolutions— Why not offered to H.R.U.S— Bell of New-Hampshire. Taylor’s conversation with Calhoun, who hopes there will be no interruption of kind feelings.

20. VII.E. Wyer here— G. Hay His circular to Governors of States on the Slave indemnity affair. Tennessee Resolutions in the Legislature of Virginia. Hay’s opinions of T. M. Randolph, and of Mr Jefferson— Says Jefferson is an insincere man; and is the Bell-wether of Virginia— And that at the time of the Seminole War controversy
he wrote to Mr Monroe in one way, and spoke to Edward Coles in another— Hay’s conversation with T. Ritchie on that occasion; when he told Ritchie that E. Coles lied; and if he did not, somebody else did. At the Office— Constant succession of visitors— Strong of New-York, about Peletiah Fitch’s claim— Jennings of Indiana— Dewey’s appointment, and Noble’s disappointment— Says Noble told him, he believed I had withheld his Letter from P.U.S— Dwight—Recommendation of Ellery for Navy Agent, Newport Rhode-Island— Caucussing. Bailey with Henderson, claimant as Representative of Coll. John Laurens. Greer about a claim of R. and J. Oliver at Port au Prince— Wyer with J. S. Barbour. Friendly visit— Chevallié and Blount here this Evening. John and Abigail, at a party at T. Munroe’s. Drowsy—idle.

21. VII. Heard at the Capitol, a Mr Mitchell, a Universalist. from John 17.3. Visits after, to Lloyd and Breck— Then to Webster and the party at Coyle’s and next to Reynolds and the company at Claxton’s. Johnson Hellen came from Rockville— John met him on the way— Afternoon at Mr Baker’s— A Stranger, from 1. Thessalonians 5:17. an excellent discourse. W. Lee here at the beginning of the Evening. Latter part of it at Thornton’s. Brown’s, Manigault and Coxe there— Salazar and Palacio— Large Mail.

22. VI:15. Morning visits from Mr Vance, with General M’Arthur, members of the House of Representatives from Ohio— From Mr Burton, with Governor Branch a Senator from North-Carolina. And from T. Newton, with Captain Elliot of the Navy. Burton recommends a Mr Murphy, and also Mr Stokes the late Senator for a mission to Mexico— W. Plumer was also here— Conversation, about the Caucus— Bell’s speech— At the Office— Torrens came with his Credential as Chargé d’Affaires from Mexico— Also a Letter to the President, sealed, from the Mexican Regents— I asked him for a copy of it which he promised to send me tomorrow— R. Smith came to ask if an American vessel could after landing part of a Cargo at one placed in England, could go from Port to Port— Mr Brown came; going the day after to-morrow to New-York upon his Mission. Talk about his passage in the Cyane— M’Rae’s mission, explained to him— Eve at home—idle—

23. VI:30. Rain the whole day— At the Office. James Brown. Going to morrow. Verbal Instructions, respecting Alr. M’Rae and his Mission. Lord Londonderry’s Letter from Hanover to Sir Charles Bagot.
Torrens came with a copy of the Letter from the Regency of Mexico, to P.U.S.General Call came concerning affairs in Florida. Borrowed a plan of the City of Pensacola— Says Florida will have in four years a population sufficient for admission to the Union as a State. Forsyth, Chairman of Committee of Foreign Relations H.R.U.S. brought me a copy of a Resolution offered this day by Mr Mallary of Vermont, asking information of the designs of the European powers relating to Spain and South-America— Forsyth was unwilling to oppose the Resolution, but asked if it would be desired by the Executive that it should be opposed— I thought not, but took the Resolution to the President’s where I dined, with the Florida Treaty Commissioners, and a company of about 35 men— I left it with the President— Mrs Adams’s evening party was notwithstanding the badness of the weather attended by near 150 persons— Trimble spoke to me of Mallary’s Resolution—and told me he wished to offer a Resolution ecchoing back the Sentiments of the President’s message, and would be glad if I would communicate confidentially with him on the subject. E. Wyer was also this day at the Office— Webster at the President’s spoke of calling for papers relating to the Brig Macedonian— I told him if he would call at the Office to-morrow, I would show them to him— He said he would come. Letter from S. Smith about discriminating duties. Charles came.

24. VI:30.Rice here about Metropolis Bank Stock. Johnson Hellen, and Antoine agreed to transfer theirs— Mr Newton was here and introduced Messrs.Loyall, Moran, and Dr Archer of Virginia— At the Office— Larned went off for Norfolk— M’Ilvaine about the District attorney’s appointment in New-Jersey— Says Jeffers was the only supporter of the Administration. Note from Southard. Secretary of the Navy, Porter’s question how far he is to protect the Spanish ship Montezuma— At the President’s. He sent for Mr Southard— Question left undecided. P.U.S. spoke of Mallary’s Resolution. Asked me to prepare a report on it to him, and said he would tell the house we were negotiating on the subject, and could not now communicate the documents. I drafted and sent to S. Smith, a bill concerning discriminating duties— Dined with Baron Tuyll the Russian Minister. The Emperor Alexander’s birthday— Diplomatic dinner— Gaillard and Clay there— Heads of Departments and the Corps— Told him where to place Gaillard and Clay— His repugnance— Remarks after dinner upon Brown, Pinkney and Middleton— Clay’s remark that this was the anniversary of the Treaty of Ghent— His remarks upon Mallary’s Resolution— Shewed his propensity to censure the Administration. Petry and Chevallié here— Cards.

25. VII. Christmas day— Call on Mr Bradley of Vermont. Slade there. Then at Dowson’s to see S. Smith but he was out. Livingston gone to New-York. Call on Newton. Instructions to Rodney— Call at M’Leod’s to see Plumer. He was out— Saw Baylies at Mrs Queen’s. Met M’Cormick— Call upon N. Edwards of Illinois. Then upon C. B. King: returned and sat to him about an hour. We had company to dine— Blount, CarterD. P. Cook, Dwight, H. W. Edwards, Fuller, Huntt, Newton Mr. and Mrs. W. S. Smith, Mr and Mrs G. Sullivan, and their two Sons.— Mr and Mrs Frye, could not come— Evening conversation with G. Sullivan— Massachusetts claims— His disappointment.

26. VII:30.B. O. Tyler was here, just returned from New-York. G. Sullivan, deeply mortified at the President’s decision upon the claim. Shewed me some of the papers. Called again at the Office—said Calhoun had told him the President had decided—came again and shewed me a Letter to him from Adan, at Boston— Visit from Dodge, just arrived— Call on P.U.S. with a draft of Report and Message on Mallary’s Resolution. He had written minutes for a Message, himself. Calhoun came in—he sent for Southard and Wirt. Discussion upon the Message— Wirt for communications to Congress. Clay’s remarks to Southard and Calhoun at Baron Tuyll’s— Question undecided. I spoke afterwards to P.U.S. on the Massachusetts claims; and am to see him again upon them— Said he had not spoken to me of them before, from delicacy. That he had fully admitted the portion of the claims already audited was not subject to the Constitutional question; but feared the payment of it now, would be imputed to intrigue— Spoke of referring it to a meeting of the whole Administration— Postponed most of my remarks till tomorrow. Dined at home, and evening idle— I walk between burning ploughshares.

27. VII:Coll. Dwight and Mr Hayden here, again to recommend Hunt as a judge for the territory of Michigan— Mr Barton, Senator from Missouri with D. P. Cook, to enquire for Instructions to Coll. Stoddard, Commandant of Upper Louisiana in 1804— Mr Bailey came and spoke of the remonstrance against his Election, and the proceedings of the Committee. Said they might perhaps send for me, to which I have no objection— Mr M’Kim with a Letter from a friend of his to Mr Brown, concerning a claim on France for a cargo seized at Amsterdam, and delivered by Treaty to Napoleon in 1810. T. Cook was here to see Johnson Hellen— At the Office young Bourne to take leave, going with Mr Brown to France— Allanson, from New-York, for a place. Bailey again. Letter from M. Morton— Mr Wirt with Mr Hollins of
Baltimore, wishing to examine documents among the archives of the Department, for vouchers of claims on Spain. He is to come on Monday— Mr Hemphill to enquire for a Mr Hunt concerning a claim of the Estate of Ira Allen upon the British Government. Call at the President’s with despatches from H. Dearborn at Lisbon— Conversation concerning G. Sullivan, and the Massachusetts claim— Sullivan had been this morning with the President, who says he is satisfied— He says he will recommend to Congress an appropriation for the whole claim— I told him of the situation of the claim with reference to the Administration of Massachusetts, and the views of W. King— The President admitted that King himself had been paid, because he was a friend— At 4. O’Clock, attended a Meeting of the Columbian Institute at the City Hall— Annual election of Officers. Then dined together at Brown’s Hotel— Calhoun of the party— M. Dickerson. Home about 9— Adlum of the Georgetown vineyard was at my house this morning.

28. VII. Heard Mr Bascom, Chaplain to the House of Representatives, at the Capitol—from John 3.16. Preached nearly two hours, by mistaking the Clock one whole hour— Very animated—ingenious—eloquent, and tiresome— The house was crowded, but the patience of some gave out, and they went away, before he finished. After the service, I called on Mr D’Wolfe and saw Mrs Morgan— Dodge was out and Morgan confined to his chamber— Called also on Webster who is unwell, and on S. Smith, with whom I spoke about the discriminating duty Bill— They have adopted my draft in the Committee of Finance of the Senate, with two amendments, and striking out the limitation, and the other striking out the words American Independent Nations—because Macon was afraid they would include Hayti. I told Smith that we had not acknowledged Hayti, as an Independent Nation, and had not thought of them in drafting the Bill— Found Wyer at my house when I came home— His talk of R. King. Heard, Mr Hamilton, a Methodist preacher at Mr Baker’s, from 2. Timothy 4.6.7— Another very long Sermon—above an hour. Evening wasted— Talk with Johnson Hellen. Mrs Adams unwell.

29. VII. I called at G. Sullivan’s house, but he was not at home. He came afterwards twice to the Office: having been with the President, and conferred with him upon the Massachusetts claim— He read me a Letter that he had prepared in reply to one from the Secretary of
War, and told me the whole subject would be referred by the President to a Cabinet Meeting to-morrow— He said Calhoun had changed his views concerning the claim since November— He had been for settling the portion of the claim not subject to the Constitutional Claim, without recurrence to Congress— He was now for referring the whole to that body— Major Gamble came to the Office, and a Mr Nones from Norfolk; applying for the appointment of Consul at Porto Cavello— An appointment has already been made— Mr Bradley of Vermont called, and had a conversation with me; he had just seen Mr Calhoun, who made many protestations as usual. He says Clay told him he must not be surprized if within 6 Month’s, Crawford’s partizans should be more bitter against him, than against any other of his competitors— W. King told him that the New-England federalists with the minority of Republicans, would carry Crawford or Calhoun; he rather thought the latter— Evening at home— Blunt spent an hour here.

30. VI:Mr R. King of the Senate, called upon me this Morning, with the discriminating duty bill; to which he suggested some Amendments. He spoke also of Mallary’s Resolution and foreign affairs; and of certain proceedings at Richmond, and in North-Carolina. Mr M’Kim and Mr Owen of Alabama came, the former with a Letter recommending Saml Huntington, as Consul at Jacmel. The latter, to make enquiries concerning Spanish Colonial Land Laws— At the Office, Captain Randall came to enquire when I should be ready to despatch him— Will call again next week. Sullivan upon the Massachusetts claim. Poinsett, and Hamilton of South-Carolina to introduce a Mr Fishburn— Crowninshield, to recommend one appointment of a Consul, and with objections to another— He read me a Letter from Sprague, about federal party movements— Interrupted by a Summons from P.U.S. to a cabinet Meeting— Calhoun, Southard and Wirt there— P.U.S. read his correspondence about W. King and the Hartford Convention in 1814 and 1815— Read Sullivan’s project of a Letter to Calhoun— Views of P.U.S. Large part of Massachusetts claim, not subject to the Constitutional question— Yet thinks the whole must go to Congress— Wirt asks, why not pay it? Wirt says Congress will never allow the part to which the Constitutional objection applies— I then asked that Sullivan’s project of a Letter be returned to him to strike out the disavowal if he thinks proper— No decision— Three Classes of the Massachusetts claim. Calhoun to prepare estimates of the amount of each— Meeting adjourned after 5. Mr and Mrs Frye dined with us. Judge Cranch and James Greenleaf here in the Evening— Then Fuller— Webster’s Resolution—to be postponed— Bailey’s case— Sullivan here again— Decided against the Claim’s going to Congress.

31. VII.D. Brent here to say that Captain Hull was going to Norfolk. B. O. Tyler with subscription paper for Slade’s book. Shewed me a Letter from F. Johnson, denying all Coalition of Clay with Crawford. G. Johnson here— Unpromising account of his business— At the Office— Sullivan with draft of a Letter to Governor Eustis. I advised him before sending it, to shew it to the President— Wyer came to say that General D’Evereux would call on me— At P.U.S. met Mr Anderson—the Comptroller there. Captain Hull came in—and afterwards to the Office— Gave him a Letter and despatches for H. Allen at Norfolk. He went in the Steam-boat at three— Message concerning the condition of the Greeks, sent in to the House— Letter to President of the Senate and Speaker of the House, with the Portrait of Columbus, sent by G. G. Barrell— Eve at home, writing.

Day. Rise at 7. Write till 9. Breakfast—read, write and receive visitors till one— Attend at the Office, and at the President’s till five or half-after—home—dine at six— Evening till eleven, reading newspapers, writing Journal—abroad; or with visitors at home. The multitudes of persons whom I see, distracts my mind— It is only in Solitude that the Soul collects itself for action—
